Firefox is miles better compared to Chrome(ium) for privacy because you can tweak it to remove the spyware much more easily. There is a reason Tor Browser is based on Firefox and not in Chromium.

> [nickwa](#comment_429_1EFZ3dYDWVpD4kF5H9PF83HjPAehEEKKJj): The only benefit Firefox has is privacy in my eyes. You make it seem like I don't actively use Tor.

Then begin thinking from a perspective of "what can we get done from here" and stop calling out people for random inane reasons that are of no consequence at all.

>Mozilla actively combating "fake news" is a real issue
No, it's fucking not. When was the last time it blocked you from seeing a site or even showed you a warning for wrongthink? Never. And besides, as I said, calling out someone for preferring one of two evils is retarded and disruptive on your part. The REAL issue is every accessed URL is sent to Google for malware detection purposes. THAT is the real issue, not some lefty PR they did or whatever.
>and why they should not be supproted.
I never said they should be supported (as in donations). Other kinds of "support" are irrelevant.
>They also kicked out Brendan Eich for a decade old donation "against gay marriage" during a time where even Obama was against it.
>All I am doing is calling you guys out for your bullshit. I cannot support companies that also bring up decades old shit against somebody.
You have no idea how things work, do you? The executives at Mozilla aren't going to change their policies because of some nobody calling them out on some random message board. Almost all of the money they're getting is from big tech companies donating to them. It's surprising they are making a usable browser at all. It's sad that there are people posting on here who don't have the IQ required to realize that and behave pragmatically rather than throw an autistic fit for no reason.

> [z0z0z0z0z0z0z0z0](#comment_7_12zcNM3BD6QwkonPrnCdbWBnGzu9b1rQRA): You have the point. Zeroid in today's form si (closed source) bullshit and weakness.Do you have solution?

I don't know what he thinks is the solution, but to me the solution is to extend ZeroNet's authentication related functionality in the API so additional authentication methods can be built on top of ZeroNet, and to allow sites to ask the user to install plugins to extend the client's functionality. nofish has mentioned working on some kind of index system that would allow generating anonymous auth_addresses from the master seed, which would cover the first point I mentioned to some extent.

> [gitcenter](#comment_902_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): if fake 200 users can do harm, it means that real 200 users wouldn't do the same.
The difference is people come here to read real people's comments, not fake user's comments. So no, 200 real users wouldn't do the same.
>Personally, I don't see any problem in bots registering IDs.
They alreaady can do so, as you obvious proven here. In fact it's very easy to do, just two HTTML requests and waiting until your certificate is received.
>From my point of view, ZeroTalk should support some kind of whitelist: you specify what users you want to read.
Oh, come on. Whitelists would be extremely impractical. Not to mention any semblance of anonymity would be lost if everyone is required to have a stable ID to have any hope of being read by other people.
>Posts/comments from those users rise up. Non-whitelisted posts/comments are either hidden or made almost transparent.
See the above. We should go in the direction of more anonymity (while maintaining or improving humanness guarantees), not less.

> [gitcenter](#comment_904_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): There are bad people too. They could be paid.
All threat models require an adversary with finite resources. Otherwise I could say it's hopeless since those same people could be paid to storm datacenters and ISPs with guns until they track down every ZeroNet client and cut it off from the Internet.
>Hehe. Haha. Cough-cough. It took me several days to register accounts, and nofish counterattacked all my attempts to leave the script running at night when I'm sleeping.
Really? What did he do, other than the regular throttling of IPs?
>Being anonymous means that you can break everything anonymously. If you have several accounts, that's rather easy to do.
But it doesn't mean you can break everything anonymously forever.
Maybe some ideas from anonymous cryptocurrencies like Monero could be borrowed, as in those systems it's possible to prove the originator of a transaction has some resources without revealing who the originator is. So people could prove they are upstanding members of the community without revealing their identity.
But for this to be possible at all we need a way for ZeroNet users not to always identify themselves in the first place without having to fiddle around with user.json files.
